concept.title: Risks and Precautions in Typewriter Lubrication
concept.shortdesc: There are important precautions for lubricating a typewriter, as improper lubrication can cause mechanical damage, attract debris, or create safety hazards during typewriter maintenance.

ul.li: Excessive lubrication attracts debris, forming thick residue and restricting movement of mechanics.
Heavy oils such as motor oil, WD-40, or household lubricants are too viscous for delicate mechanisms.
Rubber components such as the platen, rollers, or feeders will degrade when exposed to oil. This results in cracking and residue transfer to the ribbon and paper.
Exposed mechanisms, including the segment, vibrator, and line-spacing assemblies, collect dust when oiled. This reduces performance and increases maintenance needs.
Aerosol lubricants and solvent-based sprays may dissolve paint and lead to residue buildup.
Oils and cleaning agents emit fumes that can irritate the skin, eyes, and lungs. Fumes may be flammable in enclosed spaces.

conbody.note: Using small amounts of light oil only on essential metal connections minimizes wear without attracting debris or causing damage to exposed or rubber components.
